### Discussion 24: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT]

**Original Post:**
This is for all the newbies who are struggling/doubting themselves.

Valuable lesson learned from flag football:
My 9yo is on a flag football team, and he's the youngest and the smallest kid on the team.  He's also one of the fastest and has a ridiculously good throwing arm with great accuracy.  Unfortunately, his coaches won't give him a chance at QB because of his size, and the kid they play at QB isn't accurate enough to throw long passes.  Last game, I watched my son start to give up.  He was sitting on the sideline with tears in his eyes, trying not to cry and visibly sinking in to sadness.  He was avoiding looking at me so that he didn't melt completely in to tears, but at one point he glanced at me and I mouthed "it's ok" and pointed at my heart and back at him.  His coach I think noticed his change in temperment, too, and a few minutes later he was put in on defense.  I can only assume that he was told to rush the quarterback, because as soon as the ball was snapped my son forced him back 10 yards.  The next play, he did it again.  And his entire body changed after that.  He held his head up, he smiled, he started enjoying it again.
After the game, I pulled him aside and said "listen to me.  There are going to be times that you don't get the shot you think you deserve.  And in those times, you'll have 2 choices.  You can give up and stop trying, and that's ok.  You can make that choice.  But if you do that, no one will ever give you that chance again.  Or, you can choose to go back out and prove to the doubters why they should've believed in you in the first place.  And that's what you did today.  You made them see why they have to give you a chance.  Because you're worth it."
Today has been discouraging, and frustrating, and a little teary on my end.  But I've replayed that conversation in my head a few times, and decided to listen to myself.
It's SUPER hard to start a small business, especially when you're competing with 100 other options.  But it's our job to bounce back and prove why we can't be ignored.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** We have so much to learn from our kids and how we choose to guide them through life. Just know you're being an amazing example in every way, especially having the courage to start and flourish in your own business. I have a 4 and 6 year old and started 2 years ago

> **Response 2:** Love that! Also, remind the coach that Stetson Bennett didnâ€™t get a chance to play QB either, and then won Back 2 Back Natties!

**Original Post:**
I am contemplating adding a subscription type service for PT.  A monthly fee.  I am wondering if anyone here had successfully done something like this?  

I starting completely mobile, but am now hybrid.  I want to grow my in person/clinic visits and hoping to add some value by doing this.  

Any insight from someone who has done thus would be appreciated.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** The concept works. It makes it easier from a billing standpoint. Allows for less administrative work. 

Your best bet is to limit how many visits per month. Plus you need a certain number of people ready to sign up. 

Say you only have 15 people the first 6 months that have subscriptions. If you're charging $200 to $250 per month, you're only bringing in $3000 to $3750. It would seem like charging more would be the thing, but people are already paying monthly for health insurance. If you're in a more affluent location, this may be fine. So location/population are key factors. Also having enough people that want to sign up for it. 

Subscription models for PT aren't common and it may take more convincing for others to join.

Pairing up with organizations/clinics that do concierge model of Healthcare is important.

I don't have all the answers to this model. I've been trying it out for a while. It has its plus and minuses.

> **Response 2:** I'd be interested if anybody does this monthly subscription model for PT in states like California where you'd have to get the POC signed within 30 days or X # visits.

Explain to me like Iâ€™m a PT toddlerâ€¦in a Cash Based Wellness setting can Medicare patients cash pay? How do I document  to reflect Wellness only?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I feel like everyone is over complicating this. The OP said cash based welless practice....

It depends on what services you are offering this person in your "cash based wellness setting". If it is truly a service like personal training or fitness related and doesn't fall under physical therapy, then absolutely you can accept cash. 

Now you can't just rename it wellness if it truly is a physical therapy service, that requires the care of a physical therapist and you are treating a specific diagnosis.

But if they're seeing you just simply to get stronger, get in better shape, lose weight, etc and it doesn't fall under physical therapy, you can charge cash.

I hope that helps a bit!

> **Response 2:** â€œPatient is able to perform independent ADLs and self care, but is seeking additional interventions to improve tolerance and skill for recreational activitiesâ€ 

Can really write whatever you want. Have a justifiable reason and get an ABN and youâ€™re fine. Medicare is not going to come after you for saving them money, youâ€™re just justifying receiving cash in case a patient tries to get reimbursed on the back end later. If you make sure they know itâ€™s not covered you are unlikely to ever have an issue.

**Original Post:**
I currently have a cash-based mobile PT side hustle that I plan on doing full time soon. I was approached by a local PT who has a booming business (>6 month wait list) to work in her office (still be my own biz owner). She mentioned taking 20% of each visit for my patients and 50% of each visit when I see her patients. My patients are defined as anyone I bring in (for example, if I treat one of my mobile patients in the office) and her patients are anyone who calls to see her (so if someone calls to see her and learns of the 6 month wait list and doesn't want to wait, she'll direct them to me). 50% seems really high to me so I'm curious to get other's opinion's on this! For context, she has a great reputation, >20 years experience, has mentioned she'd be willing to teach me in some specialized areas and otherwise is very flexible with no min number of days/hours required and I would still work for myself. That being said, it's still 50% for a finders fee and I would be doing all of the work with the patient. Since I'm just going from side hustle to full time, I am a bit nervous about building up a case load and this would be one way that could majorly help with that. Does anyone else practice in a similar model? What % split seems fair and reasonable given this situation? I'd love to hear all thoughts an opinions! Thanks

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** When you hire someone you plan to pay them 30-50% of the revenue they bring in. It sounds like sheâ€™s looking at it like youâ€™re an employee

> **Response 2:** I can understand why this may sound as if the price is skewed to her benefit, but IT SHOULD BE! I won't advise on numbers or percentages but will offer you the view from the other side of the coin. When you are just starting out as your own business, it may seem as if the therapist is doing all the work(providing care to the pt and completing the documentation) and yes this is the revenue for the business. However, you need to realize how much goes into the greater picture of running a business than just treating patients and as many people in this group are just starting out, the full picture isn't visible yet(it wasn't for me until this year as I decide to grow my business with additional team members, services, products). As she is a business owner of a brick and mortar clinic, >20 years of experience, high reputation and an impressive 6 month waiting list, she has done EVERYTHING!  She has put in her time, effort, risk, sleepless nights, 60-80 hr work weeks, covering any shift a staff can't, learning HR/bookkeeping/accounting/compliance/risk mngmt/leadership and the cost/time each entails, mistakes in hiring/pricing/policies/EMRs/risk mngmt/scheduling, overcoming and improving on her processes to avoid those same mistakes in the future, cost of property, marketing and advertising,  paying staff instead of herself probably during slow times and so MUCH more!!!  She is also taking a risk on bringing any practitioner or employee into a business she has built for 20 yrs. Her profit margin is not 50% if she pays you 50%. If the business runs on a 5-10% profit margin and she pays a % higher to her team, that's a significant loss in the margin, so as the CEO, that comes out of her CEO salary so to speak. The COST of Attraction, Aquisition and Retention has been Tens of thousands each year for 20 years in addition to overhead costs of admin, environment, etc. We, as a profession, are kind, good-willed humans, and we can be that while being a business owner also, which includes setting your boundaries on what it is worth to the owner to continue running the business. Referring patients out would be giving away her very hard earned Attraction and Aquisition potential to only to give it to someone else for their profit. There is a great likelihood that referring them to someone like a new Uncaged clinician, she will not get them back because that Uncaged member is going to do everything in their power to retain that client, right?  So then she would have worked for years on Attraction and Aquistion(the most costly for the owner) only to give the source of revenue to someone else. That first phone call can make or break a client, so that's the most important call, that's when you get the commitment from the client. For the same reason becoming Uncaged is risky, is the very reason she must work her numbers wisely. Imagine working diligently to get your schedule up to your first 10 clients, your max,  and having to give them to someone else for no return on investment to you. She has INVESTED 20 years of building trust and respect of the community!  Huge accomplishment! Congratulations to her!  Now you just have to decide if you want to be part of what she has already built or if you are ready/willing/capable of doing the same.   Either way, choose what is right for you. Respect the process. Even if you were to work with her and didn't appreciate the numbers, you may be able to learn lots just being involved in her system with your new frame of mind as a new business owner. The whole point, there's another side to the coin. Thanks for letting me share. Good luck no matter what you decide!

### Discussion 91: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT]

**Original Post:**
Help! I am starting a mobile side business in CA. I just opened an S-Corp as we canâ€™t do an LLC here. When meeting with my accountant for personal taxes he told me it was crazy to open an S-Corp prior to having 60/80 K in profit and I should just be a sole proprietor. He recommends that I un-incorporate as s-corps are extra steps and expensive in CA. I did the s-corp so my personal assets are protected but he insisted that a good insurance would cover that. This is against any and all recommendations that I have received. Any thoughts/recs??? I am so irritated about the prospect of starting the process over as I am just about ready to start accepting clients! Thank you in advance.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Regardless of what your CPA says, you as a PT can establish ONLY an S-Corp in CA. The CPA may not be aware of that

> **Response 2:** I actually don't think any of the below answers are correct. You don't HAVE to be an s-corp because s-corp is a tax designation entity. It has nothing to do with the structure of your business. Physical Therapy practices cannot be LLCs in California but individuals can elect to be either a sole proprietor or professional corporation. All professional corporations in California are registered as c-corps initially but can file form 2553 to become an s-corp. The benefits of an s-corp is that taxation is passed on to the shareholder (you if you're the only owner of this corporation) instead of being taxed at the corporate level as well. I don't know the full scope of how profit levels might affect how this pans out but I can say from personal experience that it's fine if you have yours designated as an s-corp. But at the end of the day, consult with another trusted CPA if you want sound advice for your specific circumstance.

### Discussion 114: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2025-12-17 19:36:31 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation

**Original Post:**
Has anyone gone from cash-based to in-network? I love my clinic and what we doâ€¦ but since I hired another therapist I canâ€™t get enough clientele to make overhead. But then if I switch I feel like Iâ€™m going to end  up like every other mill in my town and I refuse to do that.  But I know others in here do insuranceâ€¦. I saw my bosses in my old jobs rolling in dough while I was barely make ends meetâ€¦. How does insurance reimburse these days?  I have someone trying to convince me to be a multi-specialty clinic because it reimburses moreâ€¦ is that true? Has anyone done this?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I see this a lot, so Iâ€™ll be direct but hopefully helpful.

Most of the time the issue isnâ€™t cash vs insurance. Itâ€™s that cash practices expect being cash + good clinical care to magically solve hiring and filling schedules. That works when youâ€™re solo. It breaks the second you hire.

When you were alone, you had low overhead and lots of time. You could network, run workshops, meet people, hustle. Your hire is not going to do that at the same level, and they shouldnâ€™t be expected to. At that point, you need real systems.

Cash pay clinics that scale well all have a few things in place:
â€¢ Strong sales skills from the first phone call through the eval
â€¢ Clear package presentation (you have to sell packages)
â€¢ Continuity options so people donâ€™t disappear once pain improves
â€¢ An intentional marketing channel that doesnâ€™t rely on the ownerâ€™s time

On the insurance side, one thing I saw in the comments stood out. If BCBS reimburses better than your cash rates, thatâ€™s a pricing issue. Your cash rates are too low.

I totally get wanting to help more people, but once you charge anything above $0, youâ€™re already excluding someone. So you might as well price in a way that lets you run a sustainable business, pay staff well, and not burn out. Donâ€™t pick prices everyone can afford. Pick prices that support the business and the life you want.

Multi-specialty can reimburse more, but it also adds complexity and doesnâ€™t fix weak sales or marketing. Plenty of multi-specialty clinics still struggle for the same reasons.

Before jumping in-network, Iâ€™d fix sales, marketing, packaging, and pricing first. Cash pay can work very well, but only when itâ€™s run intentionally.

> **Response 2:** in what part of the country are you located?
In network benefits (BCBS) vary a lot depending on location.

Giving each employee the benefit of the doubt, in the beginning, is the best approach, in my opinion. 

Be direct and honest with her about YOUR needs as an employer/business owner, while simultaneously demonstrating understanding for her situation.

**Original Post:**
Need some thoughts on an opportunity. I currently treat both MCR and cash pts with my fully mobile practice . I charge $150/visit. I was approached by a local country club with a large membership. They would like me to treat their members at the club. They would take 20% of monies. I told them $175/ visit (the idea is to recoup the 20%).  I would be there for maybe 4-5 hrs at a clip. Am I being greedy to ask for the $175/visit? Thoughts on $175 for eval and then $150 return visits? Thanks, everyone!!!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Someone in a pelvic floor group I follow put it this way: â€œI just paid $200 to have a clown at my kids bday party for an hourâ€. Consider that when setting your rates.

> **Response 2:** Iâ€™ve actually have done this in the past. Worked well but the must earn their 20% , I believe it was 20% for me as well 

1. You cannot treat Medicare there unless you get that site blessed by Medicare 
2. The country club better have all the equipment you need to effectively do your job 
3. The country club likely will be handling all the money up front ie drawing from their members accounts on a monthly basis   So you need to ensure your books are accurate so they pay you correctly 
4. The country club should assist you on scheduling their members with their front desk/spa staff. 
5. They should also market on your behalf as 20% of 10 clients vs 100 clients is much more advantageous to them. 
6 your rates seem low but all of that is area dependent, and what you are comfortable charging. We aee 275 eval 175 follow up 350 ultrasound diagnostics. Commonly an eval will pull in $625 in an hour  and the members love it.

If I only saw 2-3 patients/week, they said it wouldn't be worth it. I think I can cover the lower end of the monthly rent with one person's 10-session package BUT I'm worried about "will I have time for myself?", "will seeing 10 patients/week be too overwhelming?", "what if I can't even get people to buy in my services and now I have to cough up my own money to pay the rent" if I end up going this route. **Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** $1000/month for a 1000 Sq ft gym seems excessive. See if they are willing to give you a per hour rate. I pay $25/hour where I do side stuff. Normally only a few patients per week.

> **Response 2:** At first glance that sounds too high of rent for so a side hustle. If they really wanted you, I would try to negotiate a percentage of your billed amount.

1. Can I legally work with Med B as cash pay(out of pocket)..?

> **Response 1:** Firstly there is no cap. Medicare covers medically necessary skilled therapy services.  You can charge cash for services that are not covered by Medicare or do not meet the above criteria. **Original Post:**
Anyone offer a stretch lab kind of a service. We are planning to introduce something similar in our clinic. I would like to learn more. Do we need any special certifications? Our clientele is patients with neurologic deficits.
Thank you.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Shouldnâ€™t be any other certs neededâ€¦ I mean, you are a PT. 

Weâ€™ve not pulled the trigger yet on doing this, but I do recommend going to a few Stretch Lab, Stretch Zone, Stretch MD sessions first.  See what they really do. 

I did. Booked the free one. Bought a package. Went and enjoyed. Pay close attention to how they do it. Figure out how you could do it better.  Figure out how you can spend 25min hands on, without stopping and giving the client an exercise to do on their own. I actually gave the stretch practitioner feedback for hand placementâ€¦ they were doing good but needed some refinement. 

Actually liked it enough that I looked into buying a franchise, but had my reasons and ended up not doing it. It truly wasnâ€™t that expensive. 

BUT one of the thingsâ€¦.

Each visit is going to cost you b/w $30-$50 (package vs pay per visit). Great. That isnâ€™t bad. 

But on the other end, that person is going to come to you and pay you $30 to $50. Which is a copay. Which kind of sucks. 

Nowâ€¦I know this is an uncaged thingâ€¦ if you bill their insurance because theyâ€™re coming to you for a back or neck issueâ€¦ weâ€™re talking much different money. A 23-25 minute stretch session billed as Neuro ReEd AND get the copay. 

So you market it this wayâ€¦.â€why go to a stretchy place and get stretched by a guy who spent a weekend in Lauderdale learning how to do this, when you can come to me â€”who did 8 years of school learning itâ€” AND I can give you a couple of exercises to do at home as well. And if the stretching isnâ€™t just exactly what you needâ€¦I can get more in depth. Maybe some dry needles. Maybe a quick crack. maybe a couple of strengthening things as well.â€

> **Response 2:** Somebody has to say it, so I'll be that guy. I would hope we would use our education as PTs to rid the world of this nonsense. Neat for a feel-good treatment, but not for people seeking an evidence-based answer to their pain. I get that there's a market for it and money to be made, but it feels cheap to me and is harmful to the identity of our profession. If anyone is out there providing stand alone stretching as a service, they better not be asking why people don't understand what PTs do and what our education level is.

**Original Post:**
Is anyone willing to share their single visit rate vs package rate and how they went about deciding if packages were a good idea?   Currently I donâ€™t offer packages but considering it as a way to offer a more affordable option to those who need it.   Thank you!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I did primarily packages for about a year and now have switched to $150/session. Honestly has just been better all around with everyone paying the same rate and losing less in discounts all over the place. I do offer paid in full options for anyone who wants nothing to do with Superbills/insurance and just wants to pay in full for 12 sessions. Those are 10% off but I rarely use those now

> **Response 2:** The rates people are sharing will fluctuate depending on location, specialty, and if mobile/concierge. Consider a sales tactic called price anchoring where you have a significantly higher single session rate and packages that seem like a great discount. This pushes people to get the package, which leads to more money upfront and commitment from the patient's end to complete the POC. Individual sessions can lead to drop off/no show when the patient stops seeing the value or if there isnt an immediate change

### Discussion 284: [HIGH ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2023-06-26 13:25:32 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation
**Engagement:** 3 reactions, 15 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1269269037177659/

**Original Post:**
When applying for a new job, can the new employer see or have access to previous salary. Iâ€™m leaving my current employer to go to a clinic where in my interview they mentioned I would qualify for up to $15 per hour more. ï¿¼

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** They can call your old employer and ask for salary, but they may not do that, and your old employer may not give them the information even if they ask.  That would be the only way for them to get that info.  There are a lot of "what if's" in that scenario.

But my question is-- why do you care if they know?  It's irrelavent what you made before.  If the new employer is offering to pay more, and/or your old employer was underpaying you, that's obviously why you want to leave (and a very good reason to leave at that).  The only numbers that are important here are the standard/average pay for a therapist with your education and experience in your area, and the cost of living in your area.  Demand what you're worth, and don't let them dictate that to you!

> **Response 2:** tell them you were making $150/hr

**Original Post:**
Superbill question.  

I'm a PT working in home with infants, fully OON.  I charge a flat rate regardless of session length.  I use Jane and don't have many families wanting superbills, but when I do I had initially been inputting codes without itemized costs and it generally worked.  Now I have my second case asking for itemized cost by code.  My visits are most often around an hour so I just divided my flat rate that way and it worked for the previous baby that always worked out to 4 units, but this baby's visits have fluctuated more, so I'm not sure what I'm supposed to do.  If I say it's 31.25 per unit that works for most sessions but there have been some with only 2 or 3 units but I still charged 125... so there is a gap.  

Doesn't seem correct to keep changing the itemized code cost.

I keep seeing people say to use prompt pay discount to arrive at their flat rate fee, but that would require me to falsely jack up my itemized cost and always then discount it (by varied amounts)?  
... But that also doesn't seem right

Sorry for the overexplain, hopefully it made sense.  Thanks for reading! ðŸ˜…

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Iâ€™ve been there tooâ€¦ I unfortunately just charged a lesser rate (2-3 units instead of 4) for those sessions. It doesnâ€™t happen often.

> **Response 2:** I would make your itemized cost equal per unit and equal the lesser unit amount and then apply discounts if the unit amounts were higher than anticipated.  E.g. $125 cash typically gets 30 minutes or 2 units, but I went for 38 minutes this visit and per 8 minute rule I could charge 3 units, but I gave a discount for the third unit, so no charge for patient Ed, but charge for neuroreed 1 unit at 62.50 and therex at 1 unit 62.50 rates. Pretty sure you can have void units on activities you don't want to bill a full unit on Jane e.g. 7 minute activity is 0 units, but still doc the activities and cite it as no charge ðŸ˜‰ just follow 8 minute rule, match number if units to total time (60 minute session is typically 4 units),  err on side if caution. People are usual pleased with discounts or write off, but frown in session to session breakdown discrepancies like there 1 unit was this amount and now it is more expensive... hope this helps

**Original Post:**
Iâ€™m looking for motivation to move into private practice. Big healthcare institutions are getting scary-lay offs, short staff though at least adherent to ethical guidelines from my experience. Chain private therapy places see a ridiculous number of patients per hour utilizing techs to deliver treatment, two evals simultaneously, and questionable quality care. While I understand they are polar different settings-my worry is that branching into private practice means almost being forced to compromise â€œethicsâ€ with respect to treatment-in order for it to be financially good. Is it this groups experience that to be lucrative in the private arena that you need to function at those ridiculous productivity levels?!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** look at the business structure of these chain private practices.  Their PT's generate plenty of revenue. > **Response 2:** Short answer: No. That is not necessarily the case, and I think this group has a wealth of people who could go into detail on how they protect their patients and their employees.

If you charge adequately for your services, you can stick with these percentages and still pay (and empower) your therapist as much or more than anyone in your area. I pay better than any popts clinic in Austin and my therapists only see one patient per hour.

**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1025819328189299/

**Original Post:**
Distraction- the first of the great killers of your business. 

There's an amazing phenomenon that happens as you start to see opportunity around you. Similar to how you start to see the car you want to buy all over, opportunity starts to show up all over the place as well. 

As a staff PT, there's no reason to see opportunity so we often close off our minds to the possibility that there are opportunities outside the traditional staff PT position. 

More and more people are starting to see that this isn't the only option and that they can become "UNCAGED." Then they start a practice and hear all the different things that everyone in this and other groups are doing and there's a level of FOMO that happens that makes us think that we need to pursue every opportunity around us. 

One of the most important things that you can do as a business owner is figure out what's working, find the opportunity (not generally the opportunities) that you want to pursue and then focus and be engaged in that and not let yourself get distracted. 

People often think coaching is only for people who need help figuring out opportunities and strategy but one of the less valued but extremely important aspects of a coach is to help keep you focused on what's the most important.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** SO TRUE!! Many recognize that the greatest value in having a coach is to keep them focused! ðŸ™Œ

**Original Post:**
Hello everyone,

I have a few questions where I am stuck currently. Sorry for the long post. 

I started my business as a side hustle and planning to go all in next year. I started with my price being below average according to other practitioners. I am cash based/out of network concierge PT. 

1. I want to increase my pricing starting January, with travel time, one on one hour, I do not think it is sustainable long term with the current pricing I have. Does any one have a letter format or any templates they use to send it to the clients? 
If I have new clients, do I tell them the new price from January, how to go forward with this? 

2. I have started offering pelvic floor PT services and added that as a specialty. I have different pricing for pelvic floor patients as compared to non pelvic floor clients. I am not very sure if I should keep the pricing different or same for pelvic floor clients, if itâ€™s higher, should I increase the time that I treat the pelvic floor patients for? 

Do any of you have different pricing for things you treat or do you keep it all the same. Any guidance or help here would be greatly appreciated. 

Thank you !

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I charge the same rate for everything that I do from physical therapy to a wellness visit. This was good advice given to me a while back. The reasoning is that if you start seeing someone for wellness and charging them one rate and then they tweak their knee and they need you to take care of that, then itâ€™s difficult to adjust the rate. So i suggest you just stick to one rate for your timeâ€¦Period. 
As for your current clients, you could grandfather them in at their current rate, or slightly increased rate, if youâ€™d like. However, if they take a hiatus from you for any reason, then I would suggest that they return at the current rate.

> **Response 2:** You also have the option of grandfathering in current clients. If it's only a side hustle and you don't have a full caseload but want to honor and keep current loyal clients, you can raise your price point for new patients but keep your price point for current patients. Some of our clinicians have done this. I did it for a couple long standing patients that I had been seeing for a long time.

Anybody with a cash-based practice take a student before? I'm working on accepting a student for their clinical but wondering what kinds of liability forms I may need the student to sign. My practice is all private and cash-pay, no insurance at all. What things should I prepare or do before taking the student? Thanks in advance!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** As a cash pay clinic there is really not much of a difference when accepting a student vs being insurance based - here are some things to be aware of to cover yourself and your business -

Make sure you have the proper liability coverage as a healthcare provider and as a business entity (OSHA, state regulations, whether you are set up as a mobile or brick n mortar or Telehealth - they are safe and not exposed to risk of themselves or your patients)

The PT school should be an accredited program and have all the necessary paperwork to help set you up as an affiliate educational site: usually they have liability coverage to cover their interns but still cover your bases on your end since they are treating your patients and working on your site or traveling with you in your vehicle) 

You have proper HIPAA, and intellectual property forms set up for them to sign. 

If you have a policies and procedures manual and since they will essentially be part of your team - make sure they read and sign off on that as well.

I would speak to the school CEC to give them a formal run down on how you run your practice and if it will fit all their requirements on number of hours worked, number hours of direct patient contact, setting up of objectives and expectations on your end as a CI.  Even interview the intern to be sure they will get what they might want to get out of their educational experience and if it meets your expectations and abilities.  

That about sums it up - reach out if you have a further inquiries.

> **Response 2:** Sorry I know this is not a direct answer to your question but I assume the student will be treating patients independently at your cash based practice. Do you think your cash paying patients will feel comfortable having a student treat them? I'm just asking because I assume they are coming to you and paying the cash pay services because of your experience and expertise.

**Original Post:**
I have a billing question for anyone who does both mobile and in-clinic visits. I recently expanded my in-clinic availability with new space, and so decided to increase my mobile rate by $20 - partly to cover gas, partly for the lost time with driving compared to in-clinic visits, and partly to encourage more scheduling of in-clinic visits versus mobile. 
My question is - I'm not sure how to change this/how this should look in my documentation, specifically on my superbills/invoices. My thought was that I should keep my per-unit rate the same, and just add the $20 as an additional fee - however, there doesn't seem to be any way to do this across the board in my documentation (PT Everywhere), I think I would have to go into each visit invoice and add the fee, which I don't really want to do because (a) it seems less transparent - I want to make sure patients see that additional fee from the beginning if they're scheduling online, and (b) time-consuming.
Has anyone else run into a similar issue? How did you set yours up?
Thanks all!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I use PtE as well. Question: Why are you trying to make your per unit rate equal you total visit rate? PtE let's you set whatever price you want. Ignore your per unit rate unless you are billing OON insurance. PtE let's you set the flat rate at whatever you want. Create a "Mobile PT Visit" service and add the $20 to the service price. You don't even to notify the patient you are charging more. When they go to book they will see the mobile visit is more expensive than the in clinic visit. They might not care or they might decide to come in clinic. I'd recommend setting up a new appointment type and charging more for it

> **Response 2:** My population is mainly Medicare so I cannot charge a fee for mobile versus clinic

**Original Post:**
Whatâ€™s up everyone. I am relatively new in the group. Donâ€™t comment much/post but really value everyoneâ€™s expertise and following everyoneâ€™s stories.

I am in beginning stages of my side hustle. Still work full time for an outpatient hospital based system. Got my LLC and am currently operating out of my home. Have 1 client at this time. Goal is to work up to 4-5hrs/week starting out and scale from there.

Reason I was reaching out to everyone is I am meeting with a local gym owner this Friday about possibly renting some space there. Does anyone currently practice out of a gym setting and if so do you have any recommendations/insight on the process of negotiating. Iâ€™ve watched some videos/podcasts but was interested in hearing from you all and if you donâ€™t mind sharing what you paid starting out especially if you didnâ€™t have much clientele built up. 

Price/month, /patient, etc. or whatever you did.

Thanks so much! Any and all feedback would be appreciated very much! Have a great day!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Hey Joe! I practiced out of a gym for a while, ended up shifting to another location because the accessibility/parking at that gym really limited patient's ability to get there. A few things I'd recommend...if you're keeping your volume small for a while like you mentioned, commission-based pricing is okay but in the long term you want a fixed rate. Even $10/patient may seem small but if you're up to 30 patients a week suddenly you're paying $1200/month so that will backfire unless you make it clear from the get go that you'll do commission short-erm up until you start seeing X patients then switch to a monthly fee. Remember that you're a big asset to the gym...you are helping them be more marketable and that should reflect in a relatively low rent - I paid $700/month which included full access to the equipment and a private treatment room. They also gave me the first 2 months free to get myself set up and get clientele in the door which was a massive help.

Make sure there is adequate parking and it's easy to get to. Due to my experience, that would be a deal breaker for me.

Do workshops at the gym. Volunteer your time 1 night a week (or charge a small fee for the workshop, either way) while you're getting going...present on things they want to hear...how to improve your overhead stability...how to lift and strengthen your back...how to improve X mobility for X lifts...how to strengthen your rotator cuff to avoid shoulder pain etc etc etc...

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Assuming payment model is the same, so looking at hourly versus hourly or paper visit versus paper visit, a fair contractor rate would be 1.075 times the fair W-2 rate.

### Discussion 606: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-11-06 01:49:59 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation
**Engagement:** 2 reactions, 7 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1593560618081831/

**Original Post:**
I have an independent contractor who will be doing home visits only.  I've incorporated an increased rate per hour to reflect the travel charge.  She will get a percentage of what is charged.  Obviously her price per unit or charge code is higher than mine in clinic.  Can I ethically do that or do I need to charge the same, and then add a travel fee?  I offer people superbills, is it unethical to charge more per unit (technically) bc of it's in the home or does that matter?  Hope this is clear, thank you!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** So, if Medicare, you cannot charge a travel fee.

 If private pay, I'd bake a travel fee into my session cost say
In clinic is $x/hr
In home is $x+20/hr 

For superbills, you could have your fee schedule set for the more expensive rate, and give a facility discount for those in clinic. I know "time of service" discounts are often used for cash rates that are lower than insurance billed rates.

> **Response 2:** If she's a 1099, she can write off the mileage herself on her taxes, so I would stick with a higher percentage of net. For example, if MCR reimburses $100 for a daily visit you could pay her $65-70/visit. Obviously, you need to cover all your expenses. But, once those are covered, then you can decide how aggressive you want to do it. I think Luna pays $65-70/visit (1099) in my area. I would also make sure she is educated on the differences in reimbursements for the various codes so she can charge appropriately. Let her see how those differences affect the bottom line, and ultimately her bottom line.

I just got off the phone with someone who would like me to work with her and her son, both of whom are covered by their auto insurance (Farmer's) for an MVA in November that was not their fault.  Her understanding is that Farmers will then sue Geico (the at-fault driver's insurance).

I would provided your normal fee for service with super bill or hcfa form provided for pt. for reimbursement.  you could also file these with auto company and their private carrier.  in my state, it must be hcfa, no superbills.,

### Discussion 686: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2022-06-16 12:09:15 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 7 comments

**Original Post:**
Quick question about Medicare self pay with ABN: Iâ€™m transitioning a patient to self pay in the next several weeks. As far as self pay rates for Medicare beneficiaries, is there a requirement that I charge the Medicare allowable rate for whatever CPT code I would be performing? For example, I plan on just doing exercising and kinesiotaping, and Iâ€™ll probably be there 30-40 min. Do I have to bill the equivalent of 2 or 3 units of the Medicare allowable for therex?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** #Compliance #ABN  "transitioning"  - what does this mean?  

Is the beneficiary completing their medically necessary POC? 

If so discharge patient and setup a "wellness" or "exercise" program.  A mandatory ABN is not necessary, an optional ABN is recommended (read instructions relative to therapy). 

Are you "stepping down" the frequency, w/beneficiary requesting to maintain frequency?  If so, issue Mandatory ABN (coded to claim) to transfer liability to beneficiary.

My strong suggestion - review ABN instructions (both ABN general instructions and ABN therapy specific guidance).

As for billing for Mandatory ABN - guidance in the instructions - Medicare does not dictate price, only HOW price is stated. Setting rates best practice....?? 

As for billing Optional ABN - Medicare does not dictate rates.

For ABN - always use #GoToSource information - for both ABN and therapy application of ABN. 

Best of luck.

> **Response 2:** If you are seeing a Medicare beneficiary and doing something that is skilled you cannot charge cash for that service.  If itâ€™s a non skilled service you can and charge whatever you want.  
If you have no relationship with Medicare - ie they donâ€™t know you exist, then there is no way for you to bill Medicare in which case charge whatever you want.

Then the husband came to our office and asked for reduction in our fee.

I spoke with the husband and told him thereâ€™s nothing we could do and it would be fraud if we reduced our amount for him to get more money back.

Well a few days later the lawyers office send us a check for $500 for the husband and $900 for the wifeâ€¦..

I emailed the lawyer and asked what happened to our original amount.

Hereâ€™s what they said: After speaking with my clients looking at the medical billing, you billed Medicare for all of Mr (husband) visits and some of Ms. (Wifeâ€™s) visits.  Under Medicare rules, providers are not allowed to balance bill patients.  The payment of $500 represents Mr. (Husbands) copays.  There should have been a separate check for Ms. (Wifeâ€™s) in the amount of $900 for the visits that were not willed to Medicare.â€

I have no idea what to even say. Iâ€™m so pissed. We charged the wife our self pay rate because she was not on Medicare. So I donâ€™t understand how the lawyers office can reimburse us Medicare rateâ€¦.

â€œ

â€œI saw a husband/wife post MVA, and I treated them for a few weeks. We just received payment for their settlement. And itâ€™s a good amount. 

Now the husband came into our office today and asked to lower our amount. The lawyer showed them what we were getting from the settlement and the husband came to us and asked to lower so they can get more from the settlement.

For those of you who do lymphedema, how do supplies get covered? Is that something the patient typically pays for or would I need to partner with a DME supply company and eat that cost out of my margins? She didn't know, apparently that was all handled by back office staff at her last job.

She says her typical practice pattern is 2-3 units of manual 97140 + 1 unit of either TherEx 97110 or self care 97535. Less commonly 97760 for orthotic mgmt. If that's the case she'd pull in ~10-20% less revenue/visit than is typical for our other patient visits and if supplies come out of my margin, I'm not sure it makes financial sense to pursue it.

I bill MCR/MCAID and OON all other payers if that matters.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I have worked in an outpatient setting and now on my own as a lymphedema/oncologist OT. It has always financially made sense for the patient to buy either bandaging supplies or compression garments- itâ€™s also the psychology of the patient buying into the program. Itâ€™s cheaper for the patients online to order if the therapist helps determine what the patient needs. Like it was said in previous comments, once the Lymphedema Treatment act goes into effect, patients will hopefully have better coverage (commenting period is going on until August 28th).

As for billing, it depends what your current clinic offers and how you bill. What the therapist is proposing her typical billing sounds about right. You definitely wonâ€™t get rich with lymphedema therapy, but check your area because thereâ€™s generally a great need in all communities with too many patients to serve and not enough therapists

> **Response 2:** Ive worked in a large hospital based clinic for many years. We started with clinic providing supplies but ended up having patients pay for supplies because of cost. We found a DME provider that will order supplies and ship them to patient (we just filled out order form and sent to vendor at eval). Some insurances do cover supplies so this particular provider runs benefits and bills accordingly.

### Discussion 809: [MEDIUM ENGAGEMENT] 

**Date:** 2024-03-28 22:48:39 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation

**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1439702036801024/

**Original Post:**
In your opinion what are the BENEFITS of cash or self pay PT? For the client not the therapist.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Transparency - you know exactly what your visit costs - no waiting to see what insurance covers, waiting to see if you've met your deductible, or paying a co-pay and then getting hit with a balance bill months later.  You can make an educated, informed, and empowered decision about your health by knowing exactly what your care will cost.

> **Response 2:** Better quality care! Usually in cash-based people have longer appointments and undivided 1-on-1 care. Typically your goals really get listened to and there is time to work through problems and come up with a good, detailed HEP to help make improvements. **Engagement:** 1 reactions, 4 comments

**Original Post:**
Hello!

I am doing physical therapy in California which means I have an scorp set up. Anybody doing contracts with home health companies full time? Or even just with one company?
My situation is that I potentially have a company to contract with at an hourly rate. I Would work a regular 40 hr home health schedule. Does anyone do this? Would I need to have any special compliance requirements on my end (something related to the modules that I do for with my current travel recruiting company, etc)?

Any feed back would be helpful!
Thanks!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** What youâ€™re doing seems super common and straight forward in Ca

1) work with CPA to get S-Corp
2) get your own insurance
3) give the HH Agency your company tax ID number
4) open a bank account under your business 
5) they pay you. Your CPA handles the rest

6) I recommend taking 35% of every check and putting it in a separate savings account to get ready to pay Uncle Sam come next tax season

> **Response 2:** So I'm based out of nj- and I did work as a contractor part-time, but hours and days were set. I also interviewed with a home health company and asked if they would pay for an s Corp and both companies act turned it down bc in NJ we have abc laws that makes it in my opinion harder for an employer to pay the s Corp or even an LLC. I'm not sure if Cali has anything similar but I learned the hard way that many didn't want to pay me as a business entity but had no issues paying me as directly. I know this doesn't answer your question, but maybe if you Google abc laws you may or may not find some for Cali that may help you

I was told to expect a salary that is on par with local insurance based clinics for this job. (I was given an exact # but am unsure if itâ€™s appropriate to post) Itâ€™s in an expensive part of the country and I worry that I will still struggle to support myself. Considering that I havenâ€™t worked full time in over 5 years, I am out fo practice with how to negotiate more for myself in a respectful way. ï¿¼ï¿¼I was a tad shocked at the proposed salary because without taking insurances, and having to deal with declining reimbursement rates, I expected the pay to be a bit more. But perhaps I am just uninformed. I hope that it is acceptable for me to ask here if cash pay clinics hiring full time employees tend to provide very similar salaries as those that are insurance based?

### Discussion 878: 

**Date:** 2025-12-16 22:51:19 | **Topic:** 02-pricing-revenue-compensation
**Engagement:** 0 reactions, 4 comments
**Source:** https://www.facebook.com/groups/uncagedcliniciangroup/permalink/1924105688360654/

**Original Post:**
Hi! I had someone reach out who was just in an automobile accident last week and was referred to pelvic floor therapy for her concerns. Iâ€™ve never treated anyone going through MV insurance - Iâ€™m OON/cash based to begin with. 

Happy to work with her but curious on other perspectives or anything to expect in terms of paper work or billing! 

Thank you in advance to everyone who responds!

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Some states have different laws about payment for services using MV insurance etc, so check that first

Otherwise, you can still so your normal practice for cash pay and be paid at time of service.

If you decide to enter into a payment agreement with their attorney, then make sure you have a letter of protection on file. You likely won't be paid until the case settles and that can take a few months to a few years. In some cases they will pay out of a "fund", but it depends on the state and attorney. Also, most attorneys will come back and try to negotiate the final payout so you want to make sure your paperwork is solid so that you don't end up having to accept a fraction of what is owed. It is possible to build in "interest" to the cost because it won't be paid at time of service, but you also have to make sure you can sustain without being paid for an undisclosed amount of time. I've had some settle in a matter of months and others that have taken more than a year. Ultimately, if the bill isn't paid, it falls on the patient at the end of the day. So keep that in mind as well.

> **Response 2:** You can stay straight cash if u want.  You can bill PIP until it is exhausted then pivot to cash.  Or wait for settlement (not recommended)

**Original Post:**
When yâ€™all are figuring out package pricing is there a rule of thumb you use or how do you determine how much to take off when someone does a 4 session, 6 session, 8, etc?

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I decided what I wanted my â€œminimumâ€ rate to be, and calculated the math up from there. For my six visit package, I offer 5% off if they commit to 6 but choose to pay as they go, or 10% if they pay for all in advance. If they choose a 10 visit package, they get a 10% discount to pay as they go, or 15% to pay up front. I have a policy for how long they have to redeem those visits, and what happens if they donâ€™t use all the visits in the allotted time.

> **Response 2:** Lots of ways to go about this. Just make sure that your "best price" is not lower than the session rate you need to stay viable. (I.e., if everyone bought sessions at your best rate, you would still be able to pay your business bills and pay yourself a living wage.)

I don't do packages, per se. If they buy the full POC that I propose at eval, they get my POC discount. Anything other than that is a percentage upcharge, based on my personal "minimum" rate.

**Original Post:**
Need some advice/words of wisdom

I moved from a full time SNF + side hustle to 3 day part time at the SNF and 2 day part time working for my cash only practice at the beginning of November. I structure it typically for 60-75 min treatments and 90 minute evals and have been ramping up to 3-4 visits a week. So right now I am still pretty dependent on the income for those visits to replace the days not at the SNF (6 visits/wk is break even with expenses) I  heavily use counterstrain as a manual technique and that is generally what brings in the clients. The colleague/mentor who introduced me to this technique and had a part time cash practice recently told me they were moving out of state and said she would recommend her clients to see me when they needed therapy. Then, she also connected with a retired PT in the area who reached out who owned several insurance base clinics in the past and extensively studied counterstrain and was certified in it. At our first meeting, he mentioned that he isnâ€™t getting satisfaction doing PRN 1-2 days a week for SNFs and doesnâ€™t want all his knowledge with counterstrain to go to waste with him retiring. He told me his goal was to help my business grow and be able to pass on his knowledge. He mentioned money wasnâ€™t important since he was retired and if I wanted to utilize him, then pay him what I felt he is worth. Of course with his business knowledge and clinical knowledge, my first thought was there was no way I can afford what he is worth. I know Iâ€™ve had a lot of these doors just open in front of me and I want to take advantage of these opportunities but looking for some wisdom on how to utilize him to grow personally and grow the business to hopefully full time but also make a wise financial decision too. Iâ€™m meeting with him a second time soon but Iâ€™ve been racking my brain on how to utilize him not just as a 2nd therapist to generate income but more as a mentor and how that would play out as well as how to pay him.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** I would have an honest conversation about what he wants you to pay him. Give him your honest situation and then ask him to tell you what he would do in his situation. Sounds like a chill dude and doesnâ€™t want to put stress on you, but trust me it will be more stressful trying to figure out what he is worth later as he either provides a lot of financial value, or doesnâ€™t.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Things to keep in mind:
- all patients must be billed equally, you only have 1 charge sheet. This does not change depending on how someone can pay (insurance vs non-insurance)
- in general, all charges and possible discounts must be available to all patients equally, providing they meet the guidelines (my assumption here is that "former patient" status would be considered an arbitrary guideline based on legal aspects, but IANAL)
- discounts after the fact can be applied depending on circumstances, as long as legal guidelines are followed (such as a documented financial hardship form)
- if someone pre-paid for services before the price change went into effect, those would be grandfathered in (to the best of my knowledge, again, IANAL, just very interested in safeguarding my own practice). 

There are patient safeguards and license requirements that disallow the charge for a service to be different for patients based on arbitrary guidelines (like old vs new patients). Grandfathering may be nice, but you'd want to consult actual legal advice based on your local laws in conjunction with national laws to make sure you're not putting yourself in a legally compromised position.

In reality, when I raised my cash pay rates $25 for an hour of service I gave my current patients 2 months notice and let them know that in trying to balance a reasonable cost vs service vs keeping the doors open, that's where the numbers ended up. I had zero cancellations from those conversations because I let them know in advance and discussed the legal restrictions I have in regards to having a single charge master.

**Community Responses:**

> **Response 1:** Put whatever you want to charge, more than Medicare rates, and Medicare is going to adjust it to their rates anyway. After you create the invoice for that DOS, then you can go back to the claim and scrub it
